data.event: The primary settlement in town, where 5,297 people resided at the 2010 census, is defined as the Newmarket census-designated place, or CDP, and is located at the junction of New Hampshire routes 108 and 152, adjacent to the Lamprey River.
Incorporated in 1727, Newmarket is one of six towns granted by Massachusetts in the last year of the reign of King George I.

event.title: granted by Massachusetts in the last year

data.event: Incorporated in 1727, Newmarket is one of six towns granted by Massachusetts in the last year of the reign of King George I.

event.title: was granted full town privileges by the legislature in 1737

data.event: It started as a parish of Exeter, and was granted full town privileges by the legislature in 1737.

Beginning with the first cotton textile mill in 1823, the Newmarket Manufacturing Company dominated the mill town's waterfront and economy with seven textile mills harnessing water power at the falls.
